data.text:
Former NBA star Charlie Villanueva has opened up about the hit-and-run incident that wrecked his luxury car and left him feeling "thankful to see another day".

The 39-year-old, who played for the Milwaukee Bucks in his 11-season career in the NBA, was involved in a frightening incident when another car rear-ended his Mercedes G Wagon.

The former basketball star was travelling with his wife Lala when the perpetrator hit them from behind before allegedly fleeing the scene undetected.

Fortunately, there were no fatalities or serious injuries as a result of the crash, but Villanueva and his wife suffered injuries to their neck and back due to the impact.

Charlie Villanueva a victim of hit-and-run

In a video clip uploaded to social media on Wednesday night, Villanueva showed the extensive damage to his car and conceded that they were lucky to escape without any significant injuries.

"If you wondering what happened, my wife and I got hit bad by another car, and the crazy part is that whomever hit me, decided to run," Villanueva wrote on Instagram.

"Sore neck, sore back, messed up car, we are thankful to see another day. Our lives can't be replaced, but the vehicle can."

Villanueva praised God for keeping them safe and sent a message of hope to his 183,000 followers ahead of the New Year.

"2023 is just preparing us for 2024," Villanueva said. "So to those whom 2023 has been a difficult year, a year of struggle be thankful, and don't give up, because once you come out of the storm, you'll see your true power."

Villanueva played for the Toronto Raptors, Milwaukee Bucks, Detroit Pistons and Dallas Mavericks during his esteemed career before retiring from the sport in 2016.

The father-of-two spends his time nowadays rebuilding houses as a developer. He is also a spokesman for the NAAF (National Alopecia Areata Foundation), as he has the autoimmune skin disease known as alopecia universalis, which prevents hair growth on the scalp.
